title: Quality Over Quantity? LLM-Based Curation for a Data-Efficient Audio–Video Foundation Model
author: Ali Vosoughi (University of Rochester), Dimitra Emmanouilidou (Microsoft Research), Hannes Gamper (Microsoft Research), ... , James Glass (MIT)
relevance_why: The framework proposed for audiovisual data alignment and curation can enhance tasks related to audio-language modeling and data-efficient training, which aligns with Dr. Liu's interests in audio generation and data curation.
background: Training models that can efficiently align and retrieve audio-visual content without relying on text, using a curated data approach to improve model performance.
contribution: This paper introduces the Audio-Video Vector Alignment (AVVA) framework to solve the challenge of aligning audiovisual content efficiently, achieving significant accuracy improvements with less curated data.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often rely on large, uncurated datasets or require textual mediation to align audio and video.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work emphasizes a dual-encoder approach with LLM-driven data curation, producing a unified audiovisual embedding without the need for textual prompts.

key_innovation: Utilizes a Multimodal Reasoning Engine that combines outputs from language models to score and filter audiovisual pairs, enabling text-free alignment.
real_world_impact: The increased efficiency in data curation can lead to better-performing audiovisual models in real-world applications such as video understanding and multimedia search, reducing the reliance on large datasets.
limitations: The computational overhead of using multiple large language models in the data curation pipeline may hinder scalability.

new_terms.Multimodal Reasoning Engine: **Multimodal Reasoning Engine (MRE)** is a system that uses different large language models to assess the quality and alignment of audiovisual content, facilitating better training data curation.
